source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Corrosion exposures carried out in 633 K water revealed that all welds had excellent corrosion resistance at this temperature

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion exposures carried out in 673 K steam indicated that the laser and EB welds were susceptible to accelerated corrosion, whereas the TIG welds were not

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: EMA revealed that the welds which underwent accelerated corrosion always exhibited tin, iron, and chromium depletion in the fusion zone

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: laser and EB welds which were subjected to multiple fusion passes exhibited more severe alloy depletion levels than did single-pass welds

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: TIG welds sustained no measurable depletion

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Corrosion tests were performed in 18.6-MPa, 633 K water for cumulative exposures up to 224 days

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: in 10.3-MPa, 673 K steam for exposures up to 112 days

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: the majority of the sheet-to-sheet welds were fabricated using a pulsed yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) laser and included specimens that experienced from as few as one to as many as five fusion passes

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: using a defocused electron beam (~20 μm in diameter)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: Impurity levels (carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen) within the weld and base metal were investigated using AES

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: selected welds were mounted in the ultrahigh vacuum chamber of the Auger spectrometer after suitable metallographic preparation

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: Auger spectra were obtained after 10 and 20 min of sputtering with 2 keV Ar+ ions at a beam current of ~100 μA/cm²

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: metal removal rates of ~100 Å/min

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: Analyses were performed in the solidified weld pool and in base metal regions

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk2
evidence_span: Postweld annealing studies were performed to determine whether thermal anneals would ameliorate accelerated corrosion

evidence_span: Specimens from each of these two groups were given the following postweld anneals: 1, 8, 24, and 48 h at each of the temperatures 773, 873, and 973 K

STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Welds having little or no alloy depletion have greater resistance to accelerated corrosion at 673 K than do those that have suffered more severe depletion.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Electron microprobe analyses indicate that almost all of the laser and EB welds exhibit tin, iron, and chromium depletion, whereas TIG welds exhibit no depletion.
specimen_state: laser weld, EB weld, TIG weld

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Multiple fusion passes increase tin, iron, and chromium depletion.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Tin, iron, and chromium depletion occur simultaneously and to a first approximation to the same extent.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Interstitial impurity levels in the laser and EB welds are usually comparable to that of the adjoining base metal
specimen_state: laser weld, EB weld, base metal

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: multiple welding operations decrease interstitial impurity levels in both laser and EB welds

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Postweld anneals do not restore good high-temperature corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: welds which do not exhibit tin, iron, and chromium depletion do not undergo accelerated corrosion in 673 K steam

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: multiple welding operations produce progressively lower alloy contents in the weld, and progressively higher corrosion rates at 673 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Corrosion performance at 633 K was less sensitive to alloy composition than at 673 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: lower iron, chromium, and nickel contents were sufficient to provide good corrosion performance at 633 K than were required at 673 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: extreme depletion effects (>60 percent) are required before any significant effect on 633 K corrosion performance would be observed

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: rapid cooling rates improve the high-temperature corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: all of the welds have corrosion resistance comparable or superior to that of the adjoining base metal at 633 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: postweld anneals should have a consistent and reproducible effect on weld corrosion performance if the precipitation of second-phase particles controls corrosion resistance

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: the accelerated corrosion observed at 673 K can be avoided by selecting laser or EB welding conditions that do not produce excessively high energy densities within the fusion zone

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: laser, EB, and TIG girth welds perform comparably and equivalently to Zircaloy base metal when corrosion-tested at 633 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: laser and EB girth welds can experience severe accelerated corrosion at 673 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: TIG welds ordinarily do not experience severe accelerated corrosion at 673 K

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: multiple weld passes can significantly degrade the high-temperature (673 K) corrosion resistance of laser and EB welds

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: the best available explanation for the poor high-temperature corrosion behavior of the laser and EB welds tested in the present investigation is alloy depletion due to the high power densities that were incident on the work surface

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: alloy depletion and subsequent accelerated corrosion can be controlled by judicious selection and control of welding parameters

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: All laser welds were performed in an argon environment

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: The loss of tin would be expected to decrease the strength of the metal in the weld pool
